issues.description: The problem statement / UML specifies numberOfInscribedStudents as an int, but the solution declares numberOfInscribedStudents as a long. This is a cross-artifact attribute type mismatch: the UML (problem statement) and the expected method signatures imply int, while the solution uses long. This inconsistency will confuse students about the intended type and lead to signature/type mismatches in getters, setters and the constructor.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the attribute type across artifacts. Change the solution's numberOfInscribedStudents from long to int (and update the constructor parameter type, getter and setter to int) so it matches the UML/problem statement. Alternatively, if large counts are intended, update the problem statement/UML to use long and adjust all method signatures and documentation accordingly — but prefer making the solution use int to match the stated UML.

issues.description: The getTotalNumberOfStudents() method is specified/expected (UML/problem) to work with int totals. In the solution the method is declared to return int but its implementation adds a long (numberOfInscribedStudents) and an int (numberOfGuestStudents). This leads to a long expression being returned from a method with an int return type (incompatible types) — a compile-time error and a structural inconsistency between attribute type and method return type.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the type mismatch by making the underlying attribute type and method return type consistent. Preferred fix: change numberOfInscribedStudents to int in the solution so the addition is between ints and getTotalNumberOfStudents() can safely return int. Alternatively, if totals may exceed int, change the UML and method signature to use long consistently across problem statement, template and solution.
